46.39.text:
This is the Tadano ATF 70G-4 and the 70 stands
for the maximum capacity of 70 tonnes and

52.14.text:
the 4 stands for it being a four axle crane.
This model comes in a standard Tadano branded

57.41.text:
box, but it is a limited edition commissioned
by Heavy Transport Models and it is in the

62.03.text:
colours of Kibag, the Swiss construction company.
Straight out of the box there is one difference

66.99.text:
with this model compared to the one in Tadano
colours and that is that this one does not

71.86.text:
include an instruction manual and that is
a pity given that one has already been printed.

88.30.text:
Out of the box the hook is already attached
because the crane was reeved in the factory,

92.90.text:
and so there is not much to do to get the
crane in road-going configuration. All we

96.22.text:
need to do is to add the counterweight, and
on this crane that can be carried on the middle

100.30.text:
of the carrier deck so that the load is spread
across the four axles, and the other thing

104.73.text:
we can add is the extension boom. It rests
on the side of the main boom and is secured

109.77.text:
in position with a steel pin. Once that is
done the crane is prepared and ready for the road.

125.60.text:
Starting underneath the transmission is very
detailed, the tyres have a good tread pattern

129.69.text:
and there is a fixed ladder at the front.
The wheels are detailed well and the driving

133.48.text:
cab looks good with its mirrors, beacon lights
and graphics. Behind the cab the detailing

138.31.text:
is excellent with mesh grilles and textured
walkway surfaces. At the back the lights and

143.19.text:
graphics look good but it would have looked
better if there had been a number plate. The

147.01.text:
outrigger beams are metal and there are smooth-faced
pistons. The cab looks very good with its

151.79.text:
seals on the windows and a highly detailed
interior. The counterweight is made up of

156.33.text:
separate pieces and there nice graphics on
the crane body. The handrails are fixed permanently

161.09.text:
in the transport position, but the boom ram
is really good because it has got a metal

164.98.text:
jacket. The pulleys at the boom head are a
single solid piece, but the hook is metal

170.39.text:
and it has separate pulleys. The extension
boom is a metal lattice and it has a good profile.

184.14.text:
Starting underneath and the functionality
on the axles is good. Each one has got separately

188.54.text:
sprung suspension, and there is also steering
on each of the axles. The range of movement

194.21.text:
is moderate but all of the steering modes
of the real crane can be set. Anyway the poor

198.76.text:
old Kibag is fed up being upside down so let's
give it a run and it moves OK in a straight

203.59.text:
line, and the suspension is certainly springy.
With the steering set the crane can turn in

208.57.text:
a reasonable turning circle, but it is always
much more fun to confuse the hell out of people

214.44.text:
so let's put on the crab steering and go from
side to side. Enough of the sideways shift

219.30.text:
we are on site now so let's set the crane
up and pull out the outrigger beams. The pads

224.08.text:
have a neat clipping system to store them
for transport and when you unhook that you

227.51.text:
can wind the pads down, and there are really
tiny locking clips supplied which are there

232.16.text:
to keep the pads centred under the pistons.
Those clips are very small so you have to

236.91.text:
be careful not to lose them, and another nice
touch is that there are plastic spreader palates

241.33.text:
which you can put under the outrigger pads.
The beams are strong and the whole arrangement

245.77.text:
is good enough to be able to pose the crane
wheels-free. The next job for the giant fingers

250.73.text:
is to unhook the hook from its hooking point
on the front of the cab, and then we are ready

256.10.text:
to raise the boom. This model is very good
because it has got a metal hydraulic ram.

261.14.text:
You can secure it at any extension with a
locking screw, and a special key is included

265.69.text:
to enable it to be locked and unlocked. This
is a high quality piece of model engineering

270.57.text:
and it works very well. With the boom up the
real crane can then rotate around and pick

275.60.text:
up its own counterweight, but in the model
world you can't quite do that because of the

280.03.text:
locking clips that stick up. So what we have
to use is the multi-fingered hand crane to

284.88.text:
secure the counterweight into position. Let's
have a look at a couple of neat features on

289.74.text:
the crane body. There is an opening cover
on the front with plenty of detail to be seen

293.99.text:
underneath, and if we rotate the crane around
and pretend we have got a fingernail we might

297.87.text:
be able to open up the side cover... yes,
that's the way, and again there is more interesting

302.68.text:
detail to be seen. This is a telescopic crane
so the sections pull out a bit like a ... telescope,

309.23.text:
and when they reach full extension they have
the usual locking clip system. Also included

313.97.text:
with the model is a dummy load and that helps
keep some tension on the hook, but the type

318.57.text:
of thread used on this model is not the best
because if you unwind enough of it the whole

323.05.text:
world goes into a complete spin. Overall though,
with the boom fully extended it is an impressive model.

340.61.text:
Let's get the tape out and see how big it
is fully extended and it reaches about 35

345.25.text:
inches or 90 centimetres. But with the extension
boom you have always got the opportunity to

350.47.text:
go large so we can unfold it and then put
a locking pin in place, and the next thing

355.35.text:
to do is then to de-rig the hook from the
end of the boom. We can then add the extension

360.52.text:
boom onto the boom head and then the connection
eyes overlap and you push in a couple of steel

365.46.text:
pins to lock it in place. With both pins in
the guide pulley can be opened into position,

371.52.text:
and then the hoist rope can be threaded through
and taken up to the top of the extension boom.

375.96.text:
Only one hook is supplied with the model and
it is not the best for single line operation

379.83.text:
so you have to bodge it a little bit to get
it to hang properly. To complete the detail

384.15.text:
you can add the hoist cut-off chain and that
is best just hooked in at the top and then

388.99.text:
clipped on to the hoist rope. With the crane
rigged you then have one more feature available

394.25.text:
and that is you can offset the angle of the
extension boom. The good thing is that the

398.74.text:
ram that is used for this is very stiff so
it will hold any angle that you want to set.

403.39.text:
The extension boom gives you some useful extra
length and it adds about 13 inches or 33 centimetres.

411.89.text:
This is another very good crane model by WSI
and the only disappointment is that the manual

416.64.text:
is not included with this version. It goes
well with other Kibag models, and the very

421.32.text:
good details and features means that overall
it is an outstanding model.
